data.title: Jim Allen
data.text:
Review

Music Reviews

The Clientele, reliably dreamy for decades, tears up its delicate formula

The long-running British band introduces drum-and-bass-tinged breakbeats, strings and dub production to its delicate indie pop.

Review

First Listen

Townes Van Zandt's 'Sky Blue' Offers Insight Into A Mercurial Mind At His Prime

A new collection of unearthed solo recordings from 1973 offers a tantalizing glimpse at the creative process of a legendarily mercurial artist.

Review

First Listen

Jason Eady's 'I Travel On' Takes A Deep, Restorative Breath

Now 13 years into his recording career, 43-year-old Eady is a grown-ass man assessing his world, not with angst or regret but with a palpable sense of satisfaction and self-worth.

Review

First Listen

John Prine Offers 'The Tree Of Forgiveness' For A Weary World

The master craftsman returns with his first new tunes in 13 years.

Nick Lowe, The Jesus Of Cool, Rocks Again With 'Tokyo Bay'

The tongue-in-cheek ode to urban blight features Nick Lowe back in rockabilly mode, featuring Los Straitjackets.

Yo La Tengo Makes Music More Devotedly 'For You Too'

Hoboken's homegrown indie-rock heroes offer a poultice for the soul from their atmospheric new album.

Oneida Opens A New Psychedelic Realm, 'All In Due Time'

Brooklyn's psychedelic warriors rein things in and trip things out all at the same time on the first single from Romance.

Tom Jones' 'Done Somebody Wrong' Lets Out A Remorseful Roar

The one-time pop idol belts an Elmore James blues burner with a mighty maturity on this track from an all-star tribute album.

Simon Joyner's 'I'm Feeling It Today' Offers Communal Catharsis

Originally debuted at Carnegie Hall just weeks after the election, the Midwestern indie-folk troubadour unveils a protest song for a new era.

Simon Joyner, 'I'm Feeling It Today'

6:47

Review

First Listen

Review: David Crosby, 'Sky Trails'

The folk-rock forefather unleashes his inner jazzbo on his sixth solo album.

Review

First Listen

Review: The Clientele, 'Music For The Age Of Miracles'

Stream the sweetly spooky return of the soft-hearted British psych-poppers.

Review

First Listen

Review: Gregg Allman, 'Southern Blood'

A rock 'n' roll lifer says goodbye on his own terms.

Review

First Listen

Review: The Blind Boys Of Alabama, 'Almost Home'

Gospel's elder statesmen reach back to their roots, seven decades down the line.

David Crosby Turns A 'Diamond' Into An Observation

Folk-rock's master of sociopolitical commentary seeks the soul behind the issues.

Stephen Stills & Judy Collins' 'Everybody Knows' Cover Closes A Bittersweet Circle

Half a century ago, they were a folk-rock power couple. Now they reunite with a tribute to the late Leonard Cohen.

Stephen Stills & Judy Collins, 'Everybody Knows'

5:25

Review

First Listen

Review: James Elkington, 'Wintres Woma'

The acoustic guitar hotshot's solo debut taps into '70s Britfolk while adding a poetic modernity.

Glenn Morrow's Cry For Help Assures Us That There Are Better 'Days To Come'

The '80s Hoboken hero who's helmed The Individuals and Bar/None Records makes a belated return to band life.

Glenn Morrow's Cry For Help, 'The Days To Come'

3:25

Review

First Listen

Review: Steve Earle, 'So You Wannabe An Outlaw'

The alt-country godfather embraces his outlaw country roots.

John Prine Has Stories Enough To Fill A Book

After nearly 50 years of songwriting, John Prine has released a book, Beyond Words, full of photos, handwritten lyrics and notations full of typical cockeyed humor and Zen-like poetic observation.

Hear Nick Lowe's Unreleased Country Cover, 'Walk On By'

Lowe's lived-in baritone is an ideal vehicle for this unreleased country nugget. All six of the albums that the new-wave and power-pop pioneer cut between 1982 and 1990 will be reissued this summer.

Nick Lowe, 'Walk On By'

2:25

Review

First Listen

Review: John Mellencamp, 'Sad Clowns & Hillbillies'

A heartland rock hero teams up with Carlene Carter for some down-home spirituality.

Pete Mancini Pays Tribute To The Byrds With 'Sweethearts Of The Rodeo'

The alt-country singer shares a vibrant love letter to the album that marked Gram Parsons' golden moment with The Byrds in 1968.

Pete Mancini, 'Sweethearts of The Rodeo'

3:17

Review

First Listen

Review: Marty Stuart And His Fabulous Superlatives, 'Way Out West'

A neo-trad country stalwart turns cosmic cowboy for a heady journey into the myths of the American West.
